text: Don't stop trying to learn until you give monads a chance. If you like looking ahead in textbooks-- the monad transformer stack is a programming paradigm in Haskell for expressing the complexity of an application stack in strongly-typed functional terms.

text:
Well I just wrote fizz buzz so it'll be a while before I even think about mastering anything
```fizzbuzz xs = [ (if mod x 3 == 0 then "Fizz" else "") ++ (if mod x 5 == 0 then "Buzz" else "") | x <- xs]  ```

text: I don't get it, haskell is fast, it has a REPL, it's lazy, safe, and staticly typed. Why isn't it used for data stuff everywhere?

text: <https://www.datahaskell.org/> Many reasons really. Getting people on board to try haskell is even harder than getting them on board to try julia. Numerics is not the community's focus, although this is a bit of chicken and egg.

text: The really phenomenal thing about haskell is that it is so interesting in it's own right, divorced from any application domain. That is also it's downfall, as it is of the most navel gazing of any well known language. I'm a big haskell fan. I think it has a warm spot in my heart no language will ever replace.

text: The advantage being static typing, and every function is guaranteed to be pure. Julia is an imperative language, despite having some functional stuff.

elements.text: The advantage being static typing, and every function is guaranteed to be pure. Julia is an imperative language, despite having some functional stuff.

text: I think you'd lose some of the goodies doing that though

text: What aspect of idris intrigues you so much?

elements.text: What aspect of idris intrigues you so much?

text:
I don't think Julia is a reasonable target.

Things compile to javascript because it's the easiest way to get into a web browser.

Things compile to C because people know C better than they know assembly/LLVM, and our C compilers are pretty amazing..and cross platform (so is LLVM).

Compiling to Julia doesn't seem like it would get you anything much.
The Julia compiler isn't amazing as a compiler.
(Outside of specialized needs Julia has for e.g. interactivity so having backedges.)

elements.text:
I don't think Julia is a reasonable target.

Things compile to javascript because it's the easiest way to get into a web browser.

Things compile to C because people know C better than they know assembly/LLVM, and our C compilers are pretty amazing..and cross platform (so is LLVM).

Compiling to Julia doesn't seem like it would get you anything much.
The Julia compiler isn't amazing as a compiler.
(Outside of specialized needs Julia has for e.g. interactivity so having backedges.)

text: <@USFA21JP3> Idris 2 has dependent/linear types which seem useful. In particular the type system gives enough information that they have a totality checker and some interactive tool where the compiler tries to guess (surprisingly accurately) what you want to do.

text: right right. also can I ask what you have in mind as projects for haskell? I'm always looking for small projects to build to help myself learn more FP.

elements.text: right right. also can I ask what you have in mind as projects for haskell? I'm always looking for small projects to build to help myself learn more FP.

text: well I have some large long standing problems that without FP would be extremely painful but need to be super fast or else they are meaningless.

elements.text: well I have some large long standing problems that without FP would be extremely painful but need to be super fast or else they are meaningless.
